items.title: Paprika Recipe Manager Privacy Policy
items.content_html:
I’ve recently gone down a few rabbit holes around iPhone to Android switch and then today I went down a Paprika vs Mela one. I ended up purchasing both Paprika apps for iOS and Mac and started tinkering around and reading thoughts on Reddit.

I came across a couple of posts about how Paprika is a nightmare for privacy. All I could think to myself was “how bad could it possibly be” and went and looked at the Privacy Policy.

Let me be clear: it’s an insane policy for a recipe app. It’s extremely broad, links and ads clicked on are not covered by the policy, and the weird clause about age…I was shocked.

Ran this through Claude to get a summary, and this is what Claude gave back:

Major Overreaches:

Collects postal addresses and phone numbers (unnecessary for recipe app) Has broad access to device files and photos beyond recipe needs Shares data with undefined “subsidiaries and affiliates” Allows behavioral advertising tracking No clear data retention or deletion policies

üì± Excessive Data Collection:

Mobile network information Traffic data and communication logs Broad device metadata access Multiple tracking technologies (web beacons, cookies) IP addresses and detailed device identifiers

ü§ù Concerning Sharing Practices:

Broad rights to share with contractors and service providers Can transfer all user data if company is sold Allows multiple third-party analytics companies to collect data No clear limits on how third parties can use the data No protection guarantees for shared family recipes

Quickly submitted a request for refund to Apple and went with Mela. Want to know Melas privacy policy?

Mela does not collect any data. If iCloud Sync is enabled, your data is stored securely in a private container in your iCloud account. Mela does not depend on or use any third-party service.
items.content_text:
I've recently gone down a few rabbit holes around iPhone to Android switch and then today I went down a Paprika vs Mela one. I ended up purchasing both Paprika apps for iOS and Mac and started tinkering around and reading thoughts on Reddit. 


I came across a couple of posts about how Paprika is a nightmare for privacy. All I could think to myself was "how bad could it possibly be" and went and looked at the [Privacy Policy](https://www.paprikaapp.com/privacy/).


Let me be clear: it's an insane policy for a recipe app. It's extremely broad, links and ads clicked on are not covered by the policy, and the weird clause about age...I was shocked. 


Ran this through Claude to get a summary, and this is what Claude gave back:
> Major Overreaches:
> 
> Collects postal addresses and phone numbers (unnecessary for recipe app)
> Has broad access to device files and photos beyond recipe needs
> Shares data with undefined "subsidiaries and affiliates"
> Allows behavioral advertising tracking
> No clear data retention or deletion policies
> 
> üì± Excessive Data Collection:
> 
> Mobile network information
> Traffic data and communication logs
> Broad device metadata access
> Multiple tracking technologies (web beacons, cookies)
> IP addresses and detailed device identifiers
> 
> ü§ù Concerning Sharing Practices:
> 
> Broad rights to share with contractors and service providers
> Can transfer all user data if company is sold
> Allows multiple third-party analytics companies to collect data
> No clear limits on how third parties can use the data
> No protection guarantees for shared family recipes


Quickly submitted a request for refund to Apple and went with [Mela](https://mela.recipes/). Want to know Melas privacy policy?


> Mela does not collect any data. If iCloud Sync is enabled, your data is stored securely in a private container in your iCloud account. Mela does not depend on or use any third-party service.

items.content_html: Toys and decorations that come with batteries included are the GOAT.
items.content_text: Toys and decorations that come with batteries included are the GOAT.

items.content_html:
Sigh…

Apple to Google Photos transfer tool is just as bad as Google Photos to Apple. Not everything transferred and a lot of photos got moved over without meta data. Very frustrating and extremely disappointing.

Besides convenience, trusting Apple or Google with your photos is a major risk. Nobody wants to end up with thousands of photos that are now missing key meta data such as date taken.

Disappointing.
items.content_text:
_Sigh..._

Apple to Google Photos transfer tool is just as bad as Google Photos to Apple. Not everything transferred and a lot of photos got moved over without meta data. Very frustrating and extremely disappointing. 

Besides convenience, trusting Apple or Google with your photos is a major risk. Nobody wants to end up with thousands of photos that are now missing key meta data such as date taken. 


Disappointing.

items.title: Consistency > perfection
items.content_html:
Love seeing the progress made over 2 months of consistent running. Started struggling to run for 3-5 min straight and pushing too hard during running segments. It’s cool to see my understanding of my posture and form growing, while also learning to keep my pace consistent.

Ran for 25 min straight this morning, no walking. That’s 2 runs in a row now.

Only upward and forward!
items.content_text: Love seeing the progress made over 2 months of consistent running. Started struggling to run for 3-5 min straight and pushing too hard during running segments. It's cool to see my understanding of my posture and form growing, while also learning to keep my pace consistent. Ran for 25 min straight this morning, no walking. That's 2 runs in a row now. Only upward and forward!

items.content_html:
For all the freedoms we talk about in the US, we surely do love being held hostage to corporations.

We haven’t had a streaming subscription in a while and when we do we only watch sports. Soccer being the dominant sport and then sprinkled with NFL, college football, and NHL playoffs. It is absolutely baffling how many different services you’re required to pay for to watch a sport!

OG Football aka soccer:

  1. Cable subscription to catch NBCSN, ABC, USA, and sometimes NBC.
  2. Peacock for many PL games.
  3. Paramount+ Champions League and Europa League and some other random matches.
  4. ESPN+ for many cup ties (FA cup) and Bundesliga/La Liga.
  5. Apple TV+ MLS package for MLS games (and this is the most reasonable offering of all of the above, as you get every single match for the entire season).

NFL:

  1. Cable for CBS, NBC, FOX in local markets to see a local team.
  2. NFL Sunday Ticket for games not carried by local broadcasts.
  3. Amazon Prime for Thursday Night Football.

Hockey:

It’s such a mess that it is not worth even listing out. The bottom line is that I cannot watch my local NHL team for less than $20/mo and for nationally broadcasted games I need to pay for ESPN+, or have subscriptions to see TNT, ESPN, and ABC.

For all the freedoms we talk about in the US, we surely do love being held hostage to corporations.

We haven't had a streaming subscription in a while and when we do we only watch sports. Soccer being the dominant sport and then sprinkled with NFL, college football, and NHL playoffs. It is absolutely baffling how many different services you're required to pay for to watch a sport!

*OG Football aka soccer:*
1. Cable subscription to catch NBCSN, ABC, USA, and sometimes NBC. 
2. Peacock for many PL games. 
3. Paramount+ Champions League and Europa League and some other random matches.
4. ESPN+ for many cup ties (FA cup) and Bundesliga/La Liga. 
5. Apple TV+ MLS package for MLS games (and this is the most reasonable offering of all of the above, as you get every single match for the entire season).


*NFL:*
1. Cable for CBS, NBC, FOX in local markets to see a local team. 
2. NFL Sunday Ticket for games not carried by local broadcasts. 
3. Amazon Prime for Thursday Night Football. 

*Hockey:*

It's such a mess that it is not worth even listing out. The bottom line is that I cannot watch my local NHL team for less than $20/mo and for nationally broadcasted games I need to pay for ESPN+, or have subscriptions to see TNT, ESPN, and ABC.

items.title: Every calendar should have this feature
items.content_html:
I’ve been trying out HEY email for about a week now. It is definitely not perfect, but it is also really not that bad.

There are plenty of things to like. There are not that many reviews online (which is concerning to me), but the negative points that I have come across, do seem to have been addressed.

The feature that I am absolutely adoring so far is the “Sometime this week” in HEY Calendar. It is so simple, yet so smart and is a really good use of the calendar.
items.content_text: I've been trying out [HEY email](https://hey.com) for about a week now. It is definitely [not perfect](https://valerakushnir.com/2024/10/08/hey-mail-yikes.html), but it is also _really not that bad_. There are plenty of things to like. There are not that many reviews online (which is concerning to me), but the negative points that I have come across, do seem to have been addressed. The feature that I am absolutely adoring so far is the "Sometime this week" in [HEY Calendar](https://www.hey.com/calendar/). It is so simple, yet so smart and is a really good use of the calendar.

items.title: Hey Mail - Yikes?
items.content_html:
My annual FastMail subscription expires in December and I have been paying for FM for 3 years now. If i stick around, this will be the 4th year. Somewhere in my drafts I have a blog post sitting about how much FM has improved my relationship with email and how much I was enjoying it. Recently I began thinking through if FM is the right subscription to keep forward and began doing research on the email market.¬†

What do I need in email

It often feels like my usage of email and paying for it is a throwing money away. I have a work email that I use for my job and my friends seem to be completely happy using firstlast1223@gmail or something similar. Yet, here I am using purchased domain names, adding catch all addresses, and assigning a specific email to each service. But, overall, here is a simple list of features that I am looking for:

  1. Professional and short email handle.¬†
  2. Shared calendars.¬†
  3. Shared mailbox set up to share with my spouse.
  4. Ability to send and receive via personal domains.
  5. BONUS: my spouse and I use the same platform.¬†

Yea, that’s pretty much it. Looking at it now it all seems so simple!

Options

The first place I looked were the regular suspects: Gmail and Outlook. Both cost about the same for 2 users, and both require having the business version of the account to be separate from the personal one. That means using personal Gmail for YT and other services, while using Gsuite for the extra features. Very similar with Outlook as a personal Office 365 subscription cannot be changed into a business one.¬†
I quickly abandoned Office business as an option due to how complex MSFT makes any account management. Google still remains an option, but kind of a last case scenario. If Gmail is where I end up going, that means I’m really going to stick with FastMail over that move.¬†

I’ve also considered free versions of these services, but I can’t get handles that accomplish my number 1 requirement. I feel like some time back I used to have firstlast@gmail but lost it. Emailing that address led nowhere.¬†

Besides Gmail and Outlook other feasible options were Proton Mail and…FastMail. Again, FM is really awesome and there is a lot to like there. It’s still an option, but I’m looking to try something different.¬†
There are plenty of other email options from StartPage, to Posteo, to Tutanota…but all have cons, and considering that my ideal scenario is my spouse and I using the same platform, the learning curve might be too steep.¬†

Here comes Hey

I’ve looked at Hey.com about a year ago, but dismissed it for being half baked and really expensive. Now, it has become…an option? Let’s review:

  1. Professional and short email handle.¬† - Yes, available!
  2. Shared calendars.¬† - Yes!
  3. Shared mailbox set up to share with my spouse. - YIKES!
  4. Ability to send and receive via personal domains. - YIKES!
  5. BONUS: my spouse and I use the same platform. - Yes…?

I won’t focus on the wins, but let’s talk about the YIKES!

Yikes Number 1

Although Hey now offers a Family plan, it’s not really a family plan. When you buy a 1Password for Families plan, it comes with a shared vault that allows you to share the passwords with others. FastMail allows to create a shared email address and a shared inbox for that address that other users on the account can utilize. I assumed that if Heys Family plan allows 4 accounts, that something like that would be viable and I grabbed an email handle for our family. But it turns out it’s a feature that is completely missing. The best Hey offers right now is linking your 2nd email account to another account, but that is it, and you cannot share it beyond that.¬†

The reason why this is a pretty big feature for us is because of school. We get emails from teachers and the school district, and a shared mailbox in FastMail allowed us to know that one of us has seen it and took action. We also used it to communicate with the school and it was easy keep up. Great use case for us and without this feature in Hey, we now need to identify if having 2 addresses for the school to use is a detriment or makes no difference at all.¬†

Yikes Number 2

It’s a big yikes mostly because of sticker shock. Currently, i pay $80/year with FastMail for 2 accounts and 3 domains. That’s pretty good!¬†
Hey would cost me $30/month for the same amount of domains. And it wouldn’t cover my spouse (another $100). And each Hey account can only be associated with 1 domain, and no this is completely separate from Hey for Families.¬†

Yikes Number 3

Hey doesn’t import old email. And okay, I kind of get it, fresh start and all that. But I might have a receipt that I need to find from not so distant future. Or, a correspondence that I want to continue.
It’s not the end of the world, but it feels like an unnecessary friction point and I think the reason behind it (fresh start) is a marketing attempt to cover the technical challenge. If users begin importing thousands of old emails, it doesn’t fit neatly into The Hey Way.

In Summary

Hey is pretty cool. It’s different and opinionated, and this blog post by Chris Coyier summarizes my feelings about the service SO WELL. It’s missing features, and it’s expensive. It has a learning curve and requires a buy in from my spouse.¬†

I kind of rushed an paid even before my 30 day trial was up. I assumed that paying will give me that shared address, that shared environment that I was looking for. The customer service has been great, so hopefully they will hear me out if within a few weeks we identify that this is not for us.
items.content_text:
My annual [FastMail](https://fastmail.com) subscription expires in December and I have been paying for FM for 3 years now. If i stick around, this will be the 4th year. Somewhere in my drafts I have a blog post sitting about how much FM has improved my relationship with email and how much I was enjoying it. Recently I began thinking through if FM is the right subscription to keep forward and began doing research on the email market.¬†  
  

## What do I need in email

It often feels like my usage of email and paying for it is a throwing money away. I have a work email that I use for my job and my friends seem to be completely happy using firstlast1223@gmail or something similar. Yet, here I am using purchased domain names, adding catch all addresses, and assigning a specific email to each service. But, overall, here is a simple list of features that I am looking for:

1. Professional and short email handle.¬†
2. Shared calendars.¬†
3. Shared mailbox set up to share with my spouse.
4. Ability to send and receive via personal domains.
5. BONUS: my spouse and I use the same platform.¬†

  
Yea, that's pretty much it. Looking at it now it all seems so simple!

  

## Options

The first place I looked were the regular suspects: Gmail and Outlook. Both cost about the same for 2 users, and both require having the business version of the account to be separate from the personal one. That means using personal Gmail for YT and other services, while using Gsuite for the extra features. Very similar with Outlook as a personal Office 365 subscription cannot be changed into a business one.¬†  
I quickly abandoned Office business as an option due to how complex MSFT makes any account management. Google still remains an option, but kind of a last case scenario. If Gmail is where I end up going, that means I'm really going to stick with FastMail over that move.¬†  
  
I've also considered free versions of these services, but I can't get handles that accomplish my number 1 requirement. I feel like some time back I used to have firstlast@gmail but lost it. Emailing that address led nowhere.¬†  
  
Besides Gmail and Outlook other feasible options were Proton Mail and...FastMail. Again, FM is really awesome and there is a lot to like there. It's still an option, but I'm looking to try something different.¬†  
There are plenty of other email options from StartPage, to Posteo, to Tutanota...but all have cons, and considering that my ideal scenario is my spouse and I using the same platform, the learning curve might be too steep.¬†  
  

## Here comes Hey

  
I've looked at [Hey.com](https://hey.com) about a year ago, but dismissed it for being half baked and really expensive. Now, it has become...an option? Let's review:  
  

1. Professional and short email handle.¬† - Yes, available!
2. Shared calendars.¬† - Yes!
3. Shared mailbox set up to share with my spouse. - YIKES!
4. Ability to send and receive via personal domains. - YIKES!
5. BONUS: my spouse and I use the same platform. - Yes...?

  
I won't focus on the wins, but let's talk about the YIKES!  
  

## Yikes Number 1

Although Hey now offers a [Family plan](https://www.hey.com/families/), it's not really a family plan. When you buy a [1Password for Families](https://support.1password.com/explore/families/) plan, it comes with a shared vault that allows you to share the passwords with others. FastMail allows to create a shared email address and a shared inbox for that address that other users on the account can utilize. I assumed that if Heys Family plan allows 4 accounts, that something like that would be viable and I grabbed an email handle for our family. But it turns out it's a feature that is completely missing. The best Hey offers right now is linking your 2nd email account to another account, but that is it, and you cannot share it beyond that.¬†  
  
The reason why this is a pretty big feature for us is because of school. We get emails from teachers and the school district, and a shared mailbox in FastMail allowed us to know that one of us has seen it and took action. We also used it to communicate with the school and it was easy keep up. Great use case for us and without this feature in Hey, we now need to identify if having 2 addresses for the school to use is a detriment or makes no difference at all.¬†  
  

## Yikes Number 2

It's a big yikes mostly because of sticker shock. Currently, i pay $80/year with FastMail for 2 accounts and 3 domains. That's pretty good!¬†  
Hey would cost me $30/month for the same amount of domains. And it wouldn't cover my spouse (another $100). And each Hey account can only be associated with 1 domain, and no this is completely separate from Hey for Families.¬†  
  

## Yikes Number 3

Hey doesn't import old email. And okay, I kind of get it, fresh start and all that. But I might have a receipt that I need to find from not so distant future. Or, a correspondence that I want to continue.  
It's not the end of the world, but it feels like an unnecessary friction point and I think the reason behind it (fresh start) is a marketing attempt to cover the technical challenge. If users begin importing thousands of old emails, it doesn't fit neatly into [The Hey Way.](https://www.hey.com/the-hey-way/)  
  

## In Summary

Hey is pretty cool. It's different and opinionated, and [this blog post](https://email-is-good.com/2024/04/30/just-thinking-about-hey/) by Chris Coyier summarizes my feelings about the service SO WELL. It's missing features, and it's expensive. It has a learning curve and requires a buy in from my spouse.¬†  
  
I kind of rushed an paid even before my 30 day trial was up. I assumed that paying will give me that shared address, that shared environment that I was looking for. The customer service has been great, so hopefully they will hear me out if within a few weeks we identify that this is not for us.

items.content_html:
Not sure if it is Milton anxiety or I am going crazy. @manton I am trying to post a roughly 5000 character post which looks great under preview. As soon as I press publish, however, all of my markdown and spacing disappears and it becomes a just one large paragraph.

I see that I’m in “red” when it comes to character count. But is this a bug or is there another limit past X amount of characters that I’m encountering?

I see that I'm in "red" when it comes to character count. But is this a bug or is there another limit past X amount of characters that I'm encountering?

items.title: Roadtrips in EV
items.content_html:
This post is not about Musk, it’s about Tesla.

I just finished my 3rd road trip of the year, with over 5000 miles driven up and down the East Coast. There is no other EV on the market that you can reliably take on a road trip. Rivian is coming the closest, yet only because of the Tesla super charger network.

The availability of the chargers is unparalleled and Tesla is a lot more aggressive about the speed of charging vs other manufacturers:

Model Y - 250kW

Rivian R1T - 180kW

Ford Mach-e - 160kW

On the most recent trip that spanned about 21 hours of driving, the total charging time was 3 hours. Google maps estimated it to be about a 9.5 hour trip each way in a gas vehicle and in my ICE vehicle it would require almost 2 tanks of gas to get to the destination. I think it is fair to say that optimistically, with stops for gas, restroom, and food would require about 45 minutes at minimum. It feels like a very optimistic estimate, but if using that as a baseline, driving an EV only added 90 minutes round trip. This is not bad at all!

The longest stop on the last trip was 52 minutes, which only was this long due to how busy the restaurant was. We charged up to 96% which is not what we would usually do on a trip. Usually you get to 65-75% and leave. And the shortest stops were 4 and 7 minutes.

In total, we stopped 10 times round trip with an average of 18 minutes per stop. The amount spent on superchargers was $114.35 cents.

If your road trip style is to drive non stop until the tank is empty - EVs are definitely not it. But that’s also not an enjoyable approach to me. I appreciate taking a little stretch/break while the car is charging. It’s a nice way to break down the drive, and it works out even better when you stop for a meal.

The availability of the chargers is unparalleled and Tesla is a lot more aggressive about the speed of charging vs other manufacturers:

> Model Y - 250kW

> Rivian R1T - 180kW

> Ford Mach-e - 160kW

On the most recent trip that spanned about 21 hours of driving, the total charging time was 3 hours. Google maps estimated it to be about a 9.5 hour trip each way in a gas vehicle and in my ICE vehicle it would require almost 2 tanks of gas to get to the destination. I think it is fair to say that optimistically, with stops for gas, restroom, and food would require about 45 minutes at minimum. It feels like a very optimistic estimate, but if using that as a baseline, driving an EV only added 90 minutes round trip. This is not bad at all!

The longest stop on the last trip was 52 minutes, which only was this long due to how busy the restaurant was. We charged up to 96% which is not what we would usually do on a trip. Usually you get to 65-75% and leave. And the shortest stops were 4 and 7 minutes.

If your road trip style is to drive non stop until the tank is empty - EVs are definitely not it. But that's also not an enjoyable approach to me. I appreciate taking a little stretch/break while the car is charging. It's a nice way to break down the drive, and it works out even better when you stop for a meal.

items.title: New Keyboard - Corsair K65 Plus Wireless
items.content_html:
I’ve been bouncing back between wireless Keychron K2 and wired Corsair K65 Lux. Keychron is a bit too tall and my wrist would get tired after while. K65 was overall great, but had a really thick cable and not very good crossplatform support. Recently came across the new K65 Plus Wireless and picked it up today on sale. Wow, really impressed and I fully expected to not like it.

  • I always thought that red switches would be loud and that’s not the case at all. Really enjoy the key travel and how quiet it is.
  • It is really compact and is shorter than both K2 and wired K65.
  • Has markings for both Mac and Windows as well as an easily readable Windows/Mac switch (K2’s is very difficult to read).
  • Really nice layout and heft for both productivity and gaming, which lacked a bit with both K2 and K65 Lux. The both leaned in too far into 1 direction.

Let’s see how the board feels after a few days, but so far so good!
items.content_text: I've been bouncing back between wireless [Keychron K2](https://www.keychron.com/products/keychron-k2-wireless-mechanical-keyboard) and wired [Corsair K65 Lux](https://www.corsair.com/us/en/p/keyboards/ch-9110010-na/k65-lux-rgb-compact-mechanical-gaming-keyboard-cherry-mx-rgb-red-ch-9110010-na). Keychron is a bit too tall and my wrist would get tired after while. K65 was overall great, but had a really thick cable and not very good crossplatform support. Recently came across the new [K65 Plus Wireless](https://www.corsair.com/us/en/p/keyboards/ch-91d401l-na/k65-plus-wireless-75-percent-rgb-mechanical-gaming-keyboard-ch-91d401l-na) and picked it up today on sale. Wow, really impressed and I fully expected to not like it. - I always thought that red switches would be loud and that's not the case at all. Really enjoy the key travel and how quiet it is. - It is really compact and is shorter than both K2 and wired K65. - Has markings for both Mac and Windows as well as an easily readable Windows/Mac switch (K2's is very difficult to read). - Really nice layout and heft for both productivity and gaming, which lacked a bit with both K2 and K65 Lux. The both leaned in too far into 1 direction. Let's see how the board feels after a few days, but so far so good!

items.title: Back in the saddle
items.content_html:
Say hello to Toothless (aka Night Fury).

I grew up riding my bike all over the place, and unfortunately fell out of the hobby as I got older. The past few years I‚Äôve been thinking about getting a road bike, and finally committed.

This is a 2023 Giant TCR Advanced Pro. I named it Toothless as a shout out to ‚ÄúHow to Train My Dragon‚Äù!
items.content_text:
Say hello to Toothless (aka Night Fury). 

![Toothless](https://cdn.uploads.micro.blog/65644/2024/media.jpg)

I grew up riding my bike all over the place, and unfortunately fell out of the hobby as I got older. The past few years I‚Äôve been thinking about getting a road bike, and finally committed. 

This is a 2023 Giant TCR Advanced Pro. I named it Toothless as a shout out to ‚ÄúHow to Train My Dragon‚Äù!

items.content_html:

items.content_html:
For about 2 years I’ve been using MikroTik hAP ac3 to run my home network. As I learned more about networking, I got more frustrated with limitations of Google Mesh (as well as data collection). RouterOS is definitely not easy and I have banged my head against the wall numerous times, but I considered it good for the sake of learning.

Now, last week I added a MikroTik Cap XL ac to the family. A friend of mine is making fun of me that I’m about to have a ceiling mounted AP, but the speed is worth it!

Last night I finally got it fully set up. The challenge with RouterOS documentation is that there are multiple versions since different devices use different licenses. Thus, finding a page that is up to date and applicable to your device is not always simple. I set up CAPsMAN and after a few reboots on the AP, everything finally clicked. The AP found the CAPsMan server and now I can control all the settings from the main router.

The range of the network has definitely grown and it’s not even mounted on the ceiling yet. The connection in the garage has always been barely existent, and I already see a dramatic difference.
items.content_text:
For about 2 years I've been using [MikroTik hAP ac3](https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B08MLB51ZS/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?ie=UTF8&psc=1) to run my home network. As I learned more about networking, I got more frustrated with limitations of Google Mesh (as well as data collection). RouterOS is definitely not easy and I have banged my head against the wall numerous times, but I considered it good for the sake of learning. 

Now, last week I added a [MikroTik Cap XL ac](https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B09H2CCVZX/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?ie=UTF8&psc=1) to the family. A friend of mine is making fun of me that I'm about to have a ceiling mounted AP, but the speed is worth it!

Last night I finally got it fully set up. The challenge with RouterOS documentation is that there are multiple versions since different devices use different licenses. Thus, finding a page that is up to date and applicable to your device is not always simple. 
I set up CAPsMAN and after a few reboots on the AP, everything finally clicked. The AP found the CAPsMan server and now I can control all the settings from the main router. 

The range of the network has definitely grown and it's not even mounted on the ceiling yet. The connection in the garage has always been barely existent, and I already see a dramatic difference.

items.content_html:
I’ve been playing with Midjourney for the past few days. It is definitely not perfect, however when it’s good it’s scary good.

Some prompts simply don’t work, for example

imagine an infographic with directions on how to parallel park

produced a totally unwanted result.

However, if we use this prompt

imagine a toon style Grim Reaper that doesn‚Äôt know anything, clueless, high def resolution, ray tracing lighting, funny

the produced result was about 90% perfect and you won’t really find imperfections until you really look for them.

I’ve used it to generate some tattoo ideas, which were decent, but only about 60% of what I actually added in the prompt. Browsing the gallery of the images from the community there are absolutely stunning examples. When I look at those descriptions they are a lot more precise than mine, which means one must know how to ask this machine to do things vs me just poking around.

Pop Art, Coastal village on a rocky shore with waves, Warwick Goble, Heinrich Kley, 2nd Century Encaustic painting on Wood, decaying paint curling and cracked, massive scale surrealism, abstract hyperrealism, iridescence, palette knife texture, exploration of form, dimensional arpeggios::2 Pop art pointillism illustration utilizing Alcohol Ink, fractal patterns, nautilus shapes, 3d spirograph depth, abstract texture, surreal nebula landscape::1

However, if we use this prompt > imagine a toon style Grim Reaper that doesn‚Äôt know anything, clueless, high def resolution, ray tracing lighting, funny the produced result was about 90% perfect and you won't really find imperfections until you really look for them. I've used it to generate some tattoo ideas, which were decent, but only about 60% of what I actually added in the prompt. Browsing the gallery of the images from the community there are absolutely stunning examples. items.title: Troubleshooting Microphone Issues
items.content_html:
Unfortunately, I often forget how much better MacOS is about A/V input than Windows. Spent about 1.5 hours yesterday trying to troubleshoot why when using my Scarlett Solo PC audio would get picked up instead of the microphone audio….well, turns out drivers is what I needed.

It’s been so long for me messing with the drivers that I didn’t even go there first, which is an oversight. But now that it’s fixed, happy to play with the 4th Gen Solo and a new AKG P120 I picked up!
items.content_text:
Unfortunately, I often forget how much better MacOS is about A/V input than Windows. Spent about 1.5 hours yesterday trying to troubleshoot why when using my Scarlett Solo PC audio would get picked up instead of the microphone audio....well, turns out drivers is what I needed. 

It's been so long for me messing with the drivers that I didn't even go there first, which is an oversight. But now that it's fixed, happy to play with the 4th Gen Solo and a new AKG P120 I picked up!

items.title: First Toastmasters Speech
items.content_html:
Did my first Toastmasters speech today!

I was mostly unprepared and haven’t spent enough time rehearsing the speech, so in many ways I was “winging it” in the moment.

I started out calmly, but as I progressed, I became super nervous. At some point I thought i will pass out :D But the audience (about 12 people in person and 3 remote) said I didn’t come off nervous at all, which is a great compliment.

I’m really proud of myself. This felt very different than speaking in a meeting and I am looking forward to improving this skillset.
items.content_text:
Did my first Toastmasters speech today! 

I was mostly unprepared and haven't spent enough time rehearsing the speech, so in many ways I was "winging it" in the moment. 

I started out calmly, but as I progressed, I became super nervous. At some point I thought i will pass out :D But the audience (about 12 people in person and 3 remote) said I didn't come off nervous at all, which is a great compliment. 

I'm really proud of myself. This felt very different than speaking in a meeting and I am looking forward to improving this skillset.

items.title: Passed SSCP!
items.content_html:
30 days after I didn’t pass SSCP during first attempt, I’m super happy to share that I did pass on the 2nd attempt!

I had 2 relatively crappy weeks preparing coming up to the retake, so I did not feel super confident. Material was mostly familiar, but the process was tough. 150 questions, 4 hours, no going back.

The biggest help on this 2nd attempt was the official app. I picked it over Pocket Prep to ensure accuracy, and it was definitely sufficient. Will use it again when studying for CCSP!
items.content_text:
30 days after [I didn't pass SSCP during first attempt](https://valerakushnir.com/2023/09/19/unfortunately-didnt-pass.html), I'm super happy to share that I did pass on the 2nd attempt! 

I had 2 relatively crappy weeks preparing coming up to the retake, so I did not feel super confident. Material was mostly familiar, but the process was tough. 150 questions, 4 hours, no going back. 

The biggest help on this 2nd attempt was the official app. I picked it over Pocket Prep to ensure accuracy, and it was definitely sufficient. Will use it again when studying for CCSP!

items.title: Fastmail to Zoho and back
items.content_html:
When I switched from Google Suite to Fastmail, I began liking email again. Fastmail’s interface is fast and simple. The updates are consistent and it has almost all of the features I would need. It’s cheaper than Gsuite. The only glaring negative was the lack of integrations, but I can live without those.

However although cheaper, FastMail is still $80 for two users while Zoho mail is $30. So for the past few weeks I switched to Zoho and have been trying it out.

It didn‚Äôt last. We are back to FastMail. Here is why:

  1. Major Issue is Zoho UX. They have serious readability issues for their inbox. Fonts make it difficult to distinguish read and unread, and the entire inbox appears cluttered. There are no options to change font sizes either, so everything kind of blends in.
  2. Unified inbox for external accounts is missing. I love that in FastMail I can fetch emails from other providers and they all come to the same inbox. Zoho separates these into separate accounts. I‚Äôd have to set up forwarding rules for everything to go to the same place which adds friction.
  3. Wildcard addresses. FastMail handles this fantastically. I can create a new ‚Äúfrom‚Äù address right in the compose screen. In Zoho I had to go to the admin console to create a new one. So if I signed up for a service with ‚Äúalias@domain.com‚Äù, although I could receive that email I‚Äôd have to create it in the admin console in order to respond with it. FastMail wins hands down here.

In the end, we know cheaper is not always better. But different, is not always better either. Zoho has a lot going for it but it created more friction to my workflow and it just is not suited for my needs.

The only glaring negative was the lack of integrations, but I can live without those. 

However although cheaper, FastMail is still $80 for two users while Zoho mail is $30. So for the past few weeks I switched to Zoho and have been trying it out. 

It didn‚Äôt last. We are back to FastMail. Here is why: 

1. **Major Issue is Zoho UX.** They have serious readability issues for their inbox. Fonts make it difficult to distinguish read and unread, and the entire inbox appears cluttered. There are no options to change font sizes either, so everything kind of blends in.
2. **Unified inbox for external accounts is missing.** I love that in FastMail I can fetch emails from other providers and they all come to the same inbox. Zoho separates these into separate accounts. I‚Äôd have to set up forwarding rules for everything to go to the same place which adds friction.
3. **Wildcard addresses.** FastMail handles this fantastically. I can create a new ‚Äúfrom‚Äù address right in the compose screen. In Zoho I had to go to the admin console to create a new one. So if I signed up for a service with ‚Äúalias@domain.com‚Äù, although I could receive that email I‚Äôd have to create it in the admin console in order to respond with it. FastMail wins hands down here. 

In the end, we know cheaper is not always better. But different, is not always better either. 
Zoho has a lot going for it but it created more friction to my workflow and it just is not suited for my needs.

items.title: A used mini fridge made me feel rich
items.content_html:
I bought a used mini fridge, stocked it with favorite drinks, and I‚Äôve never felt richer.

I‚Äôve always been really focused on not having sodas and juices around the house. In my eyes those things are unnecessary, budget busters, and of course not healthy. But they are a nice treat once in a while!

Sometimes we would buy those things, be it coconut water, sparkling waters, or something similar. Beer from time to time, or even diet sodas. It was always a nice treat to have one, even with the negatives, in moderation it would be great to have it as an option around the house

But I recently decided that in moderation. It is nice to offer it to guestss that come over. And I didnt expect how rich it made me feel.

I think this is where Ramit Sethi comes to mind. This is not an expensive thing, but it really made our life a little richer.

items.title: Dog inflitration
items.content_html:
I have a dog. I love dogs. Dogs are the best.

But people are really abusing common courtesy about where dogs are not supposed to be. I see dogs at Costco, Publix, Target, clothing stores. Today, two people brought in dogs into a kids playground.

It is a problem. People don‚Äôt train little dogs, and often large dogs as well. Trust me, your dog willl be okay without you for a little bit. Have some respect towards other people around you.

Dog tax attached.

I see dogs at Costco, Publix, Target, clothing stores. Today, two people brought in dogs into a kids playground. It is a problem. People don‚Äôt train little dogs, and often large dogs as well. Trust me, your dog willl be okay without you for a little bit. Have some respect towards other people around you. Dog tax attached.

items.title: Bsides St Pete
items.content_html:
Attended Bsides St Pete. Until earlier this year I had no idea how active Tampa Bay cyber scene is and now I found myself attending a 2nd Bsides in 1 year as well as multiple socials around ISC^2 chapter and others.

This was definitely on a smaller scale than the Tampa Bsides. Less tracks, less sponsors, less attendees. It was great to see many (now) familiar faces nonetheless.

I did not stay for the entire day and attended 3 topics:

  1. Opening talk on symptoms of burn out.
  2. Great presentation on starting the career in cyber, building home lab, and other suggestions.
  3. A “urinal story” discussing the gap in training investment into people by companies.
items.content_text:
Attended [Bsides St Pete](https://www.bsidesstpete.com/). Until earlier this year I had no idea how active Tampa Bay cyber scene is and now I found myself attending a 2nd Bsides in 1 year as well as multiple socials around ISC^2 chapter and others. 

This was definitely on a smaller scale than the Tampa Bsides. Less tracks, less sponsors, less attendees. It was great to see many (now) familiar faces nonetheless. 

I did not stay for the entire day and attended 3 topics:

1. Opening talk on symptoms of burn out. 
2. Great presentation on starting the career in cyber, building home lab, and other suggestions. 
3. A "urinal story" discussing the gap in training investment into people by companies.

items.title: Updating calibre-web to 6.20
items.content_html:
Ran into some issues updating calibre-web on my Synology server. After trying to update to version 6.20, I began receiving the following errors:

"flask-limiter" is needed for calibre-web to run. Please install it using pip: "pip install flask-limiter"

and

ImportError: cannot import name 'CronTrigger' from 'cps.services.background_scheduler' (/calibre-web/app/cps/services/background_scheduler.py) .

Thankfully nothing too major, and these two quick commands fixed it:

pip install flask-limiter

pip install apscheduler
items.content_text:
Ran into some issues updating calibre-web on my Synology server. After trying to update to version 6.20, I began receiving the following errors:

` "flask-limiter" is needed for calibre-web to run. Please install it using pip: "pip install flask-limiter" `

and

` ImportError: cannot import name 'CronTrigger' from 'cps.services.background_scheduler' (/calibre-web/app/cps/services/background_scheduler.py) ` .

Thankfully nothing too major, and these two quick commands fixed it:

`pip install flask-limiter`

`pip install apscheduler`

items.title: Starting on Micro.blog
items.content_html:
It’s been a few days since joining Micro.blog. I remember hearing about the platform on a podcast quite a few years ago, but I completely forgot it existed. I’ve been using Jekyll and Github pages quite successfully for a few years, but I found my workflow to be a bit tedious and that if I didn’t do anything with the site besides posting, with the next update or design change something would break. I’m not a Ruby expert, nor do I want to be, so it became a headache.

There are 2 main observations about Micro.blog:

  1. The community aspect is something that deserves a ton of recognition. This is, indeed, a place where you do want to write. The brief interactions have been great, and the community is very interesting. I love the fact that there is an actual community manager and weekly community events.
  2. Boy are some things not user friendly. This platform has a long way to go before it can be used by regular, non techie folks. Documentation is lacking and in some places is out of date. Without Hugo knowledge things are just hard.

But, the community aspect is outweighing the negatives. Once I’ll get to the point where my tinkering is satisfied with the way the site is set up, I can see myself sticking around here for a while and building on top of this platform.

items.title: It's Electric
items.content_html:
I made a switch from a gas car to an electric RWD vehicle. I’ve never driven an electric vehicle before and only been in one once. After a week of ownership I have a few thoughts.

I totally get it

It’s been great. It’s the fastest car I’ve ever driven as the torque is insane. The top speed is supposed to be 140MPH, but i’m not going anywhere near that. Merging onto highways and overtaking other cars when needed is a breeze. I was told I will miss the engine noise and vibrations from the lack of the engine but it hasn’t been the case for me. The road noise is comfortable and it’s quieter than the previous car. The vibrations from the engine was exactly what I never liked as it is (i’m pretty sensitive to anomalies in car sounds and it just added stress to my daily driving knowing that something might be wrong with the car ). Adding a level 2 charger at home also made a massive difference. It is extremely convenient and is about 1/3rd of the gas prices. The car also came with the Tesla Supercharger included. Even though my car is limited in speed of charging due to it’s age, knowing that I can charge for free on any road trip is great.

It’s basically a phone with wheels

Everything is an app or via a touch screen. This part is pretty annoying.

  • Unlock doors without fob? touchscreen
  • Unlock charging port? either app or touchscreen inside the car.
  • Want to change windshield wipers? dig through the touchscreen menu to put them in “service mode”.

There are apps and games, and fart noises? And i’ve had to soft reset the car several times which is also unusual. But in general, there are too many examples to list of where standard features that traditional car manufacturers have via a button are buried in the software for no good reasons. With my car being 10 years old there are improvements that they have made on newer versions, however in some instances (AC vents) they took away the manual ability to change direction and hid them in software.

Verdict

Very happy. I got a deal from a friend and I am overall very happy with the decision. The break even point is over a year but this calculation does not consider the fun factor that I am having driving this car. Surprisingly, lack of transmission opens up the space a lot, allowing my dog to fit in better and join us on more trips. And with having a hatch AND a frunk, we can actually fit more into the vehicle than our SUV.
items.content_text:
I made a switch from a gas car to an electric RWD vehicle. I've never driven an electric vehicle before and only been in one once. After a week of ownership I have a few thoughts. 

## I totally get it

It's been great. It's the fastest car I've ever driven as the torque is insane. The top speed is supposed to be 140MPH, but i'm not going anywhere near that. Merging onto highways and overtaking other cars when needed is a breeze. 
I was told I will miss the engine noise and vibrations from the lack of the engine but it hasn't been the case for me. The road noise is comfortable and it's quieter than the previous car. The vibrations from the engine was exactly what I never liked as it is (i'm pretty sensitive to anomalies in car sounds and it just added stress to my daily driving knowing that something might be wrong with the car ).
Adding a level 2 charger at home also made a massive difference. It is extremely convenient and is about 1/3rd of the gas prices. 
The car also came with the Tesla Supercharger included. Even though my car is limited in speed of charging due to it's age, knowing that I can charge for free on any road trip is great. 

## It's basically a phone with wheels

Everything is an app or via a touch screen. This part is pretty annoying. 

- Unlock doors without fob? touchscreen
- Unlock charging port? either app or touchscreen inside the car.
- Want to change windshield wipers? dig through the touchscreen menu to put them in "service mode". 

There are apps and games, and fart noises? And i've had to soft reset the car several times which is also unusual. 
But in general, there are too many examples to list of where standard features that traditional car manufacturers have via a button are buried in the software for no good reasons. With my car being 10 years old there are improvements that they have made on newer versions, however in some instances (AC vents) they took away the manual ability to change direction and hid them in software. 

## Verdict

Very happy. I got a deal from a friend and I am overall very happy with the decision. The break even point is over a year but this calculation does not consider the fun factor that I am having driving this car. Surprisingly, lack of transmission opens up the space a lot, allowing my dog to fit in better and join us on more trips. And with having a hatch AND a frunk, we can actually fit more into the vehicle than our SUV.

items.title: TIL - Houston Zoning Laws
items.content_html: After listening to the episode by Search Engine podcast I learned that there are no zoning laws in Houston! Well, I’m sure there are some, but it sounds like it is pretty minor. The episode mentions a house that used to have a quiet backyard, until a rollercoaster was built there.
items.content_text: After listening to the episode by [Search Engine podcast](https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/why-cant-we-just-turn-the-empty-offices-into-apartments/id1614253637?i=1000623420256) I learned that there are no zoning laws in Houston! Well, I'm sure there are some, but it sounds like it is pretty minor. The episode mentions a house that used to have a quiet backyard, until a rollercoaster was built there.

items.title: Toxic Productivity
items.content_html:
A while ago I drastically reduced podcasts. Almost 2 years later and I haven‚Äôt subscribed to a new podcast and still listen to about 5 podcasts in total.

The problem is that I do enjoy the podcasts and there are so many out there that I‚Äôd like to explore. A friend of mine was just laughing about a podcast discussing bad dates and how hilarious it was.

Every year I set a goal for reading a cer…

items.title: EU 261 Regulations
items.content_html:
Well, this is a first. Our flight from DUB to EDI was cancelled because‚Ä¶.of a late delivery of a new aircraft.

Maybe, it is not such a special reason for more frequent travelers, but this is the first time I have experienced this. The good news is that this warning was given to us even before we arrived to the airport. The bad news is that we have to spend an extra day outside of our final des…

items.title: Bsides Tampa
items.content_html:
This weekend I got a chance to attend the Bsides Tampa 10th anniversary conference. It was my first cybersecurity conference.

The material was great, but there were 2 sobering truths to me:

THe industry is struggling with having jobs for entry level candidates. It is difficult to get your first opportunity in cyber. I hae been neglecting building my own skillset.

The 1st truth is just …
